Authors:
Kelly P. Steele, Stefanie M. Ickert-Bond, Shahin Zarre,
Martin F. Wojciechowski
Title:
Phylogeny and character evolution in Medicago (Leguminosae):
evidence from analyses of plastid trnK/matK and nuclear GA3ox1
sequences
Keywords:
Medicago, Trigonella, trnK/matK, GA3ox1, aneuploidy,
single-seeded fruits
Abstract:
The genus Medicago includes about 88 species, including
the model legume M. truncatula and a number of important forage species,
for example M. sativa (alfalfa), M. scutellata (snail medic) and M.
lupulina (black medic). Relationships within the genus are not yet
sufficiently resolved contributing to difficulty understanding evolution
of a number of characteristics such as aneuploidy and polyploidy, life
history, structure of cotyledons, and number of seeds per fruit.
Phylogenetic relationships of 70-73 species of Medicago and its sister
genus Trigonella were reconstructed from nucleotide sequences of the
plastid trnK/matK region and the nuclear-encoded GA3ox1 gene using
maximum parsimony and Bayesian inference methods. Our results support
certain currently recognized groups, e.g., sect. Medicago and sect.
Buceras. Other strongly supported clades, the “reduced subsection
Leptospireae clade” that includes species currently in three different
subsections or sections, the “polymorpha clade” that includes M. murex
and M. polymorpha currently in different subsections and the “subsection
Pachyspireae clade”, contradict the current classification. These
results allow us to hypothesize that the 2n=14 chromosome number has
arisen at least four times, that single-seeded fruits in both Medicago
and Trigonella arose more than once, and support the utility of GA3ox1
sequences for phylogenetic analyses among and within closely related
genera.
